**Task 1: Hello Web\!**  
ğŸ“ Build your first webpage using HTML.

ğŸ“Œ Step 1: Create a new HTML file using vs code. (eg. index.html).

ğŸ“Œ Step 2: Learn the basic structure of an HTML document (tags like `<html>`, `<head>`, `<body>`).  
Read this tutorial: [https://www.w3schools.com/html/html\_intro.asp](https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_intro.asp)

From the tutorial copy and paste the example code to your HTML file.

Run your HTML file by following this tutorial: [https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-enable-live-server-on-visual-studio-code/](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-enable-live-server-on-visual-studio-code/)

ğŸ“Œ Step 3: Include an image (`<img>`), and add a link (`<a>`).

 Ref: https://www.w3schools.com/html/html\_attributes.asp

ğŸ“Œ Step 4: Post the screenshot of your output (the website should include  h1, p, img, a tags) in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag **\#web-task-1.1** to earn 250 Karma points.

ğŸ“ Make your webpage look better by learning basic CSS. CSS is a powerful tool that can transform your website's appearance. With a little practice and creativity, you can create stunning designs that captivate your audience\!

     Ref tutorial: [https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/types-of-css-cascading-style-sheet/](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/types-of-css-cascading-style-sheet/)

ğŸ“Œ Step 3: Use other CSS  properties to add more styles to your web page. You can reference the above link to see all the CSS properties and try to add that in your HTML.

Be patient to read that tutorial.

**Task 4: Responsive Web Design**  
ğŸ“ Ensure your webpage is responsive across devices.

**What is Responsive Design?**

Responsive design is a technique that allows websites to automatically adjust their layout and content to fit the screen size of the device being used. This means that whether you're viewing a website on a desktop computer, a tablet, or a smartphone, you'll see a version of the site that is optimized for that particular screen.

ğŸ“Œ Step 1: Learn about the meta viewport tag and add the tag to your file.  
             Ref: [https://www.w3schools.com/css/css\_rwd\_viewport.asp](https://www.w3schools.com/css/css_rwd_viewport.asp)

ğŸ“Œ Step 2: Use media queries to adjust the layout for mobile devices.

             Ref: [https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/css-media-queries/](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/css-media-queries/)

ğŸ“Œ Step 3: Create a new web page that should have different CSS on mobile and desktop. 

	eg: [https://media.geeksforgeeks.org/wp-content/uploads/20240725200510/mediaquery.mp4?\_=2](https://media.geeksforgeeks.org/wp-content/uploads/20240725200510/mediaquery.mp4?_=2)

ğŸ“Œ Step 4: Post the video of your output by screen recording and drop it in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag **\#web-task-1.4** to earn 250 Karma points. 

ğŸ“¥ Outcome: A mobile-friendly webpage that adapts to different screen sizes.

#### **Task 1: Getting Started with JavaScript**

### **ğŸ“** Write your first JavaScript program to display a message.

### **ğŸ“Œ Step 1:** Create a new HTML file and link an external JavaScript file.

###            **How to link JavaScript?**

### There are 3 ways to use javascript in HTML (Read the article below). [https://www.scaler.com/topics/link-javascript-to-html/](https://www.scaler.com/topics/link-javascript-to-html/)

###  **ğŸ“Œ Step 2:** In the JavaScript file, use `console.log("Hello, JavaScript!");` to print a message to the console. **ğŸ“Œ Step 3:** Open your browserâ€™s developer console to see the output (Press F12 or right-click \> "Inspect" \> Console). **ğŸ“Œ Step 4:** Post a screenshot of your output (console with â€œHello, JavaScript\!â€) in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-2.1 to earn 200 Karma points.

### **ğŸ”— Resources:** The whole internet is there for you, search find ;)

#### **Task 2: Variables and Data Types**

### **ğŸ“ Practice declaring variables and using different data types in JavaScript.**

### **ğŸ“Œ Step 1:** Declare variables of each type (`string`, `number`, `boolean`, `array`, `object`). Example:

### Copy code ğŸ‘‡

### `let name = "Amarnath Sujith";`

### `let age = 34;`

### `let isStudent = true;`

### `let hobbies = ["reading", "coding"];`

### `let address = { city: "Kazhakootam", country: "INDIA" };`

### 

### **ğŸ“Œ Step 2:** Use `console.log()` to display each variable in the console. **ğŸ“Œ Step 3:** Post a screenshot of your output showing all variables in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-2.2 to earn 250 Karma points.

#### **Task 3: Basic Arithmetic and String Operations**

### **ğŸ“ Learn how to perform operations with numbers and manipulate strings in JavaScript.**

### **ğŸ“Œ Step 1:** Write JavaScript code to perform basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) using two variables. **ğŸ“Œ Step 2:** Practice string operations, like concatenation (`+`), `toUpperCase()`, and `toLowerCase()`:

### Copy code ğŸ‘‡

### `let greeting = "Hello";`

### `let name = "Chethas";`

### `let fullGreeting = greeting + " " + name + "!";`

### `console.log(fullGreeting.toUpperCase());` 

### **ğŸ“Œ Step 3:** Post a screenshot of your output (console showing results of arithmetic and string operations) in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-2.3 to earn 250 Karma points.

#### **Task 4: Mastering Arithmetic Operations**

#### **ğŸ“ Learn to perform arithmetic operations in JavaScript and display results.**

#### **ğŸ“Œ Step 1:** Create an HTML file and link an external JavaScript file. **ğŸ“Œ Step 2:** In the JavaScript file, declare two variables, `num1` and `num2`, and assign them any numeric values. **ğŸ“Œ Step 3:** Perform the following operations on `num1` and `num2`:

* #### **Addition**

* #### **Subtraction**

* #### **Multiplication**

* #### **Division**

* #### **Modulus (remainder of division)**

#### **Copy code ğŸ‘‡**

#### **`let num1 = 10;`**

#### **`let num2 = 3;`**

#### **`console.log("Addition:", num1 + num2);`**

#### **`console.log("Subtraction:", num1 - num2);`**

#### **`console.log("Multiplication:", num1 * num2);`**

#### **`console.log("Division:", num1 / num2);`**

#### **`console.log("Modulus:", num1 % num2);`**

#### 

#### **ğŸ“Œ Step 4:** Run your code and display each operation's result using `console.log()`. **ğŸ“Œ Step 5:** Post a screenshot of your output (console showing results of arithmetic operations) in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-2.4 to earn 200 Karma points.

#### **ğŸ”— Resources:**

* #### [https://www.w3schools.com/js/js\_arithmetic.asp](https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_arithmetic.asp)

#### 

#### **Task 5: Using `if...else` Statements with Alerts**

ğŸ“ **Create an interactive script to check if a user input is positive, negative, or zero.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Prompt the user to enter a number using `prompt()`.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Use an `if...else` statement to check if the number is positive, negative, or zero.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Display an alert message with the result. Example:

Copy code ğŸ‘‡  
`let number = prompt("Enter a number:");`  
`if (number > 0) {`  
  `alert("The number is positive.");`  
`} else if (number < 0) {`  
  `alert("The number is negative.");`  
`} else {`  
  `alert("The number is zero.");`  
`}`

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Run the program in a browser to test it with different inputs.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Post a screenshot of the alerts for each type of input (positive, negative, zero) in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-2.5 to earn 250 Karma points.

ğŸ”— **Resources**:

* JavaScript `if...else:` [https://www.w3schools.com/js/js\_if\_else.asp](https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_if_else.asp)  
* JavaScript Alert: [https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/met\_win\_alert.asp](https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/met_win_alert.asp)

### **Level 4: API Integration and Dynamic Content with JavaScript**

---

#### **Task 1: Introduction to APIs and Fetch**

ğŸ“ **Learn how to make your first API call using JavaScriptâ€™s Fetch API.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Choose a simple API that doesn't require authentication, like the [Cat Facts API](https://catfact.ninja/).  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Create an `index.html` and a `script.js` file. Link your JavaScript file to the HTML file.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** In `script.js`, use `fetch()` to retrieve data from the Cat Facts API and log it to the console.

**let** fetchRes \= fetch("https://catfact.ninja/fact");

 fetchRes.then(res \=\>

    res.json()).then(d \=\> {

        console.log(d)

    })

### Now check the output by right-click \> "Inspect" \> Console

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Display a fact from the API on your HTML page using JavaScript.

	**Reference**: [https://chatgpt.com/share/6726473d-c084-8011-8911-9a879bb1cb38](https://chatgpt.com/share/6726473d-c084-8011-8911-9a879bb1cb38)

ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Post a screenshot of the console showing API data and your webpage with a displayed cat fact in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-4.1 to earn 300 Karma points.

ğŸ”— **Resources**:

* [JavaScript Fetch API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API/Using_Fetch)

---

#### **Task 2: Display API Data on the Webpage**

ğŸ“ **Style and structure the API data to display it neatly on your page.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Use HTML and **CSS** to create a container for displaying the cat fact dynamically.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Add JavaScript to retrieve a new fact every time the user refreshes the page.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Style the fact display (e.g., adding borders, colors, font styles) to make it look appealing.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a screenshot of your styled fact display in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-4.2 to earn 300 Karma points.

---

ğŸ“ **Add interactivity by allowing users to fetch a new fact with a button click.**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

#### **Task 4: Using another endpoint**

ğŸ“ **Fetch data that returns an object.**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for better understanding

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** In `script.js`, use `fetch()` to retrieve data from the Cat Facts API and log it to the console.

The difference is instead of  /fact \-\>  /facts

**let** fetchRes \= fetch("[https://catfact.ninja/facts](https://catfact.ninja/facts)"); 

 fetchRes.then(res \=\>

    res.json()).then(d \=\> {

        console.log(d)

    })

Now check the output by right-click \> "Inspect" \> Console

This returns an object. Inside that object, there is an array of facts.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Display the list of facts in the HTML.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Add CSS  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a screenshot of your webpage showing data fromAPI in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-4.4 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

Advice API: [https://api.adviceslip.com/advice](https://api.adviceslip.com/advice)

ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Make a separate API call in `script.js` to fetch data from the new API.

### **Level 5: Building Your First API with Express.js**

---

#### **Task 1: Setup Node.js and Express Environment**

ğŸ“ **Prepare your environment for Express.js development.**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Install [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) if you haven't already.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Initialize a new project by creating a folder and running `npm init -y` in your terminal.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Install Express by running `npm install express`.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Create a new file called `server.js` for your server code.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Write a basic Express server that listens on port 3000 and responds with "Hello, World\!" to a simple GET request.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 6:** Post a screenshot of your "Hello, World\!" response in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-5.1 to earn 300 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 2: Create Your First Endpoint \- GET Request**

ğŸ“ **Set up an endpoint that responds with data when accessed.**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** In `server.js`, add a `/greet` endpoint that handles GET requests.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** When accessed, the `/greet` endpoint should respond with a JSON object containing a greeting message (e.g., **{ message: "Greeting, Dear" }**).

ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Post a screenshot of your JSON response in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-5.2 to earn 300 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 3: Create a GET Endpoint** 

ğŸ“ **Build a GET endpoint**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

     **ğŸ“Backend Part**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Add a `/fruits` endpoint in `server.js`.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Return a list of fruit names.

     **ğŸ“Frontend Part**  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Fetch the response from the backend to the frontend using Javascript.

API: \`[http://localhost:5000/fruits](http://localhost:5000/fruits)\`

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Display the list of fruits on the HTML and add CSS to it.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Add an image to the corresponding fruit.	

ğŸ“Œ **Step 6:** Post a screenshot of your website in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-5.3 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 4: Add a GET Endpoint to Retrieve Stored Data**

ğŸ“ **Create a way to retrieve the user data stored on the server.**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Add another GET endpoint /employees in `server.js` to retrieve all user data stored in the server variable.

     const Employees\= \[  {name: â€Mohanlalâ€, field: â€œDancingâ€, state: â€œKeralaâ€, image: â€œhttps://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Mohanlal\_Viswanathan\_BNC.jpg/1200px-Mohanlal\_Viswanathan\_BNC.jpgâ€ },

     {name: â€Mammottyâ€, field: â€œActingâ€, state: â€œTamil Naduâ€ image: â€œhttps://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcR3czM8hTAqoMWIlX5b5bJcQWl5j49vpOD1HA\&sâ€},

ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** This endpoint should return the stored user data in JSON format when accessed.

#### **Task 5: Add a GET Endpoint to Retrieve Stored Data**

ğŸ“ **Create a way to retrieve the user data stored on the server.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Add another GET endpoint `/users` in `server.js` to retrieve all user data stored in the server variable.

**ğŸ“¥ Outcome**: By completing Level 5, learners will have created a simple API server with Express.js, allowing them to handle GET and POST requests, store data in memory, manage errors, and enable CORS for API access. This lays a solid foundation in backend development and handling APIs.

### **Level 6: Server-Side Rendering with Express.js, MVC, Handlebars, and MongoDB**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

---

#### **Overview:**

Learners will create a simple app with a structured MVC pattern, using Handlebars for server-side rendering and MongoDB to store data. This project introduces them to the basics of SSR and database interactions.

---

#### **Task 1: Set Up the Project Structure with MVC**

ğŸ“ **Organize your project using the MVC pattern.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Run command  **npx express-generator \--hbs**  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:**Run **npm install** and **npm start**  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Set up the `views` directory and configure Express to use Handlebars as the templating engine.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Create a basic layout file (`index.hbs`) to serve as the template for all pages.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Test the setup by creating a simple route that renders a Handlebars view.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 6:** Post a screenshot of your layout rendering in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-6.1 to earn 300 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 2: Set Up MongoDB and Connect to the Database**

ğŸ“ **Connect your Express app to a MongoDB database.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Install MongoDB locally or use MongoDB Atlas (cloud) for this project.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Install the `mongoose` package by running `npm install mongoose`.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Create a connection to MongoDB in your project using Mongoose.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Test the connection to ensure your app can connect to the database successfully.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Post a screenshot of your successful database connection message in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-6.2 to earn 300 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 3: Build the Model for Your Data**

ğŸ“ **Define the schema and model for your data.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** In the `models` folder, create a Mongoose schema and model for a simple entity (e.g., "article" with fields like `title`, `description, author, banner`, and `createdAt`).  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Create a Mongoose schema for User.

---

#### **Task 4: Set Up the Controller and Routes**

ğŸ“ **Create routes to handle requests and manage data flow.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** In the `controllers` folder, create a controller file (e.g., `articleController.js`) to handle all interactions with your model.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Add functions to the controller to handle actions like creating and retrieving items.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Test the routes by creating and displaying data on the front end.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a screenshot of the data being displayed on the page in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-6.4 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 5: Add Basic Form Handling to Create Data**

ğŸ“ **Allow users to add new items through a form on the frontend.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Create a form in your Handlebars view to submit new items.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Set up a route and controller method to handle form submissions and save new items to MongoDB.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Redirect the user to the list page after submission, showing the updated list of items.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Test the form submission to ensure data is saved and displayed correctly.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** Post a video of the newly added item appearing on the page in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-6.5 to earn 500 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 6: ADD CSS**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Style the page using CSS for a more polished look.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Post a screenshot of your articles page in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-6.6 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

**ğŸ“¥ Outcome**: By completing Level 6, learners will have built a basic MVC-structured app using server-side rendering with Handlebars, integrated MongoDB for data storage, and enabled data handling through form submissions.

### **Level 7: Building a Blogging Application**

ğŸ¥ Video is provided for the better understanding

---

#### **Overview:**

In this level, learners will create a simple blogging application where users can create and view blog posts. This project reinforces backend development, routing, CRUD operations, and dynamic data rendering.

---

#### **Task 1: Set Up User Authentication**

ğŸ“ **Implement a login system to manage access to the blogging platform.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Install `bcrypt` for password hashing and `jsonwebtoken` (JWT) for secure authentication tokens.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Allow users to register by providing a name, email, and password.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Return a cookie to verify the user status

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a video of signing to the website in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-7.1 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 2: Article editing and deleting**

ğŸ“ **Set up routes and controllers to manage blog posts.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Create routes for editing particular article.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** In `controllers`, create methods for handling each operation with the `Post` model.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Test each route to verify all CRUD operations work.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a vide of a successful post editing and deletion in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-7.2 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### 

#### 

#### 

#### **Task 3: Stlye the entire website (responsive)**

ğŸ“ **Use CSS for styling**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Implement your own style to each page.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Each page should be responsive.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post every page screenshot on your linkedIn and share the link of the linkedIn post in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-7.3 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 4: Add a Detailed View for Individual Posts**

ğŸ“ **Allow users to view individual blog posts.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Create a new route for viewing individual posts based on their ID.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** In the controller, retrieve the post data by ID and pass it to a detailed Handlebars view.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Display the `title`, `content`, and `author` fields on the detailed view.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Post a screenshot of an individual blog post view in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-7.4 to earn 400 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 5: Push Your Project to GitHub.**

ğŸ“ **Publish your Blogging project on GitHub.**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Push your project to GitHub and create a new repository.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Share the link to your project in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the 	hashtag \#web-task-7.5 to earn 500 Karma points.

---

#### **Task 6: Hosting**

ğŸ“ **Hosting the Full stack project**

ğŸ“Œ **Step 1:** Create an account on [https://render.com/](https://render.com/)  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 2:** Connect your GitHub to Render.  
ğŸ“Œ **Step 3:** Select the particular project.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 4:** Set env variables.

ğŸ“Œ **Step 5:** DEPLOY\!

ğŸ“Œ **Step 6:** Share the link of your live project in the â task-dropbox on Discord using the hashtag \#web-task-7.6 to earn 500 Karma points.

---

**ğŸ“¥ Outcome**: By completing Level 7, learners will have created a functional blogging application, gaining experience in CRUD operations, dynamic content rendering, and form handling with Express, Handlebars, and MongoDB.
